Topic.Title: Michael Dell can offer $15.50 and make Icahn drama go away

Message.Msg: Try $14.25. Dell is in the same decline that Blackberry was. It has many unprofitable business units. Icahn is a raider, he would destroy the company, walk away with a few extra bucks for share. Nobody trusts him.

Message.Title: Great buy now
Message.Msg: What's really interesting is that if the Icahn offer happens, you are essentially buying the current stock at $1.46 and then getting $1.65 for a 13% return. Not bad.

Message.Title: SKULL SOCK-SHORT SQUEEZE $28M SHARE BUY OUT,COMING FROM 52WKS LOW-SOON $7
Message.Msg: At a current trading price of around $5.20 per share, its total market cap is around $143 million. The market is valuing Skullcandy at only 2.6 times EV/EBITDA. Compared to its peers including Harman International Industries (NYSE: HAR) and Sony (NYSE: SNE), Skullcandy has the cheapest valuation. Harman, at $44 per share, is worth more than $3 billion on the market. It has the most expensive valuation at 6.6 times EV/EBITDA. Sony isthe biggest company among the three, with nearly $15.7 billion in the total market cap. At around $16 per share, Sony is valued at nearly 4.4 times EV/EBITDA. Interestingly, Skullcandy generated the highest operating margin at 14%, while the operating margins of Harman and Sony were 7% and 0.5%, respectively. Skullcandy delivered quite a high return on capital among the three at around 40%. The return on capital of Harman was 40.6% while Sony generated net losses. Among the three, Sony has the highest forward dividend yield of 1.9% while Harman pays to existing shareholders a 1.4% forward dividend yield. Skullcandy does not pay any dividends to shareholders. In the first quarter of 2013, the company expected to generate a loss between $0.25 to $0.30 per share. Interim CEO Rick Alden admitted: “We have not kept up with all the changing trends nor have we led with our own innovations.” Indeed, I would expect the similar downtrend in the short-term for the company, indicating by the wider divergence between its operating cash flow and its net income.

Topic.Title: Icahn and SE are doing the right thing

Souhtrheastern spent years buying DELL at much too high share prices, and now that so called "money management" firm is crying because theyior DELL shares are underwater? Southeastern will lose money on their DELL investment, and lose clients because this DELL publicity has revealed Southeastern as a bunch of incompetent fools.
